notesStmt.p: This fifteenth-century love song is a virelai for three voices. Although it draws on a common theme for French songs of this period—the heartache of someone whose lover is absent—it is somewhat unusual that it is written from a woman’s perspective.

This song has been transcribed from the Chansonnier Nivelle de la Chausée (Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Département de Musique, Res. Vmc MS 57), ff.79v-80r. The manuscript can be viewed at https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b55007270r/f158.item. The same song is also found in Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale Française, 1719. Different manuscripts attribute it to either Agricola or Fesneau.

sourceDesc.p: Chansonnier Nivelle de la Chausée (Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Département de Musique, Res. Vmc MS 57), ff.79v-80r

projectDesc.p: "Oh how it troubles me!" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: et que Je me treuve esbahye
de ce que Je ne vous puis voir
mon seul tout vueillez y pourvoir
app.rdg: My one and only, please do what is necessary

app.lem: se vous amez moy et ma vie
app.rdg: if you love me and my life.

app.lem: qui me tourmentent jours et nuits
tant que Jen suis toute esperdue
app.rdg: to such a degree that I feel totally lost,

app.lem: car je ne puis [avoir] plaisir ne nulz de puis
app.rdg: for I have not been able to have any joy, nor anything else, since

app.lem: que je vous ay perdu de veue
app.rdg: I lost you from my sight.
I have no interest in anything,

app.lem: ne mon desir ne my convye
puis que mieulx je ne puis avoir
app.rdg: because I cannot have anything better
and I cannot be happy otherwise.
